stories.title: Edits to a cholesterol gene could stop the biggest killer on earth

stories.text:
Cofounder has unfortunately decided to leave our company. We're equal shareholders. Our shares vest over a 4yr period with a 1yr cliff. Since we only incorporated in February, nothing has vested, but we are both on the board.

What is the course of action here? Is there a place where I can find a template for some sort f a separation agreement that would detatch them from the company completely, including any shareholding and board positions?

Product is built but pre-launch, and, unfortunately, we are also in the middle of our pre-seed. We've incorporated a C Corp via Stripe Atlas
stories.title: Ask HN: 50/50 Cofounder leaving amicably. What now?

stories.text:
Maybe, HN is not the best place for this question, but something tells me there will be interesting stories behind it.

I saw a lot of people I knew start learning how to program. They did it in all sorts of ways: free courses, paid courses, books, schools, etc.

Almost all of them quit within weeks or months.

An interesting observation was to hear them describing why they quit too abstractly, too broadly. "I didn't like it." "Couldn't make the time to learn." "Too hard." Things like that.

I've always felt that there's so much more behind those answers. So much we could learn about why programming is so hard to enter, apart from the inherent domain complexity.

What's your story, or that of someone you've seen quit?
stories.title: Ask HN: Why did you quit learning programming?
